Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Accelerating Project Management Skills Development through "Experience"; Realistic Rehearsal for Project Teams in 3-Dimensional Immersive Virtual Environments.
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project accelerates the development of project management expertise by enabling users to rehearse tough, real-world challenges in an immersive, Virtual World environment. Studies of expert project managers indicate that their skill was acquired over many years and as a result of learning by failure. Accelerating this process would have a huge impact on the costs of real world failure. Some studies have estimated the organizational losses to upwards of $82 billion annually. These losses are thought to be largely preventable with better approaches to project management education. The broader/commercial impact of project lies in its ability to 1) lower the risk of learning through failure, 2) accelerate the time it takes to effectively train novices, and 3) alleviate some of the costs associated with unanticipated mistakes made in the real world. Using an immersive, simulation-based, outcomes driven rehearsal methodology, this product has the potential to 1) increase the success rate of projects for those with limited real-world experience, 2) by allowing users to rehearse and test deployment plans without risk and 3) by providing participants new to project management an opportunity to encounter tough problems and develop solutions under pressure.

This company's rehearsal method enables teams of participants to interact with virtual replicas of actual processes and products in the context of an ongoing business with complex goals. The primary innovation will be the use of Virtual Worlds to provide rich interactive environments to accelerate expertise development among novice project managers. The Virtual Worlds environments are enriched with embedded behavior and decision monitoring software designed to automate the tracking of progress and provide feedback. Early pilots with experts indicate that the method may accelerate expertise development by as much as two years. The objective for this project is to refine the approach for use with novices by targeting key skills of project management that are normally learned through years of experience, and specifically, learning from failure. Virtual Worlds also provide an ideal platform to test hypotheses regarding the technical implementation, individual engagement and team outcomes in a novice population. As such, the project will also resolve a number of questions about the key features at play within emerging Virtual Worlds platforms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
WTRI principals are known experts in the area of accelerating expertise in business domains.  The company has developed methods of quickly developing expertise that normally takes years to acquire through specially designed “rehearsals” of difficult business situations.    In general, these have been highly customized and tightly controlled “events” confined to small groups of senior levels executives of large corporations.  However, over the years, the company has developed several enabling technologies which showed promise for making the approach scalable.   This NSF SBIR research explored the development of a scalable product for developing expertise in project management “through experience” using prototypical difficult projects like those now confronting organizations.  

This was done by connecting WTRI enabling technologies for complex business gaming – our intellectual property – to a specially designed multi-player virtual world. 

The early tests with teams showed results very similar to custom designed rehearsals with WTRI clients; i.e., through iterative rehearsal, teams performed at levels normally seen in employees with 5 years of experience after only a few weeks after participating in the “in world” sessions only 2-3 hours a week as long as they completed the entire rehearsal sequence. 

A second phase of the research done in collaboration with the Project management Institute tested a single player version, which was a radical departure from WTRI’s experience.  PMI provided about 700 volunteers from its worldwide network over a period of a year.  Completion was voluntary and there were no negative consequences for not completing.

We analyzed the data of those that had completed the entire rehearsal sequence.   These included 203 participants.  Among this group, there was statistically significant evidence of the same learning effects seen in groups and in custom designed rehearsals (Student’s T p<.0001). 

This study showed that the basic principles proven to accelerate expertise – namely cognitive reorganization through iterative trial and error with embedded feedback – held up in both scalable, virtual world versions of the product, namely a virtual world team even hosted on a cloud server and an identical single-player application with volunteers working alone, relatively unguided,  and remotely.  In general, the product produced learning benefits much better than anticipated – especially for a product still in Alpha – and much better for something that was completely voluntary. 

We were also able to show that fundamental cognitive mechanisms must be involved; because this method had been heavily tested with groups prior to this study, it could be argued that all individuals in those groups had not necessarily undergone a change in their ways of thinking.   In the single player study, all participants were working on their own and showed measurable changes in expertise in universal and consistent ways. 

Beyond proving the robustness of the method, there are other implications.  First, it holds promise that a method confined to restricted settings and “elite teams” (mainly the military, scientists and corporate executives) can be made available to a wider set of users with benefits that may enhance their careers. 

Further, we were able to collect data that showed us how to make the approach more powerful; in other words we had the opportunity with large numbers of people to see what was working well and what could be refined.  The participants also liked the product (e.g., 84% reported it was meaningful and appropriately challenging as well as a valuable learning experience).

The strong results show promise not only for this product, but for the potential to deliver accelerated expertise educational methods more widely than thought possible for professional development purposes.   Many people are finding it difficult to adapt to rapidly changing business environments and struggle with the necessity of having to re-invent themselves constantly.  This product may the beginning of an approach that helps.
